content: The Act may be cited as the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, a key component of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, flooded the fertile bottom land of the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, impacting the national economy. The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project flooded the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, causing economic and cultural damage to the tribe. Congress has compensated several Indian tribes, including the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe. The flooding of the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation by the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project caused economic and cultural damage to the tribe. Congress provided compensation to the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe and other tribes affected by the Pick-Sloan projects. Inadequate compensation led to the enactment of the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe suffered injury from the Pick-Sloan projects, leading to inadequate compensation. Congress enacted the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act, creating a Tribal Recovery Trust Fund, but did not provide additional compensation for tribal members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act created a Tribal Recovery Trust Fund but did not provide additional compensation for tribal members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. This Act aims to allow the Trust Fund to compensate those members for their land losses. The Act aims to use the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund to compensate tribal members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. It also seeks to capitalize the Trust Fund. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe will receive equitable compensation under Section 3 of the Act. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe should be fairly compensated for the land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservation project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe and member landowners should be adequately compensated for the land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservation project.
